title: Judgment and Restoration
shortSummary: Joel chapter 3 prophesies the future gathering of nations for judgment in the valley of Jehoshaphat due to their mistreatment of Israel. It also promises the restoration and blessing of Judah and Jerusalem, affirming God's sovereignty and faithfulness to His people.
timeline: c. 9th century BC - Prophecy concerning the Day of the Lord and future judgment

keyCharacters.name: Judah and Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The people and city of God's chosen nation, whose captivity will be reversed and who will be restored and blessed.

keyCharacters.name: Nations (Gentiles)
keyCharacters.description: The surrounding peoples who have scattered Israel and will be gathered for divine judgment in the valley of Jehoshaphat.

keyCharacters.name: Tyre and Zidon
keyCharacters.description: Prominent Phoenician cities accused of exploiting Israel and thus subject to God's swift recompense.

definitions.definition: A symbolic location representing the place where God will judge the nations for their treatment of Israel.
An ancient practice of making decisions or dividing property by chance, here used to illustrate the cruelty against God's people.
A future time of God's decisive intervention in history involving judgment and salvation.
A metaphor urging preparation for war, reversing the peaceful use of farming tools into weapons.

outline.heading: Promise of Restoration and Gathering of Nations
outline.description: God declares He will restore Judah and Jerusalem and gather all nations to the valley of Jehoshaphat to judge them for scattering Israel and dividing His land.

outline.heading: Judgment on Nations and Retribution
outline.description: Specific nations like Tyre, Zidon, and the Grecians are condemned for selling God's people and profiting from their suffering, with God promising to repay them.

outline.heading: Call to Prepare for Battle
outline.description: A summons to the nations to prepare for war as the day of the LORD approaches, emphasizing the certainty and severity of God's judgment.

outline.heading: The LORD’s Judgment and Cosmic Signs
outline.description: The sun, moon, and stars darken as God roars from Zion, shaking heaven and earth, demonstrating His power and establishing Jerusalem’s holiness.

outline.heading: Blessing for Judah and Desolation for Enemies
outline.description: God promises abundant blessings for Judah, including flowing rivers and cleansing of blood, while Egypt and Edom face desolation for their violence.

application: Trust in God's sovereign justice and timing, knowing He will vindicate His people and punish the wicked.
Be encouraged by God's promise of restoration and blessing for those who remain faithful to Him.
Prepare spiritually for the coming Day of the LORD through repentance and obedience.
Recognize the importance of standing with God's people and His purposes in prayer and action.

keyVerses.text: I will also gather all nations, and will bring them down into the valley of Jehoshaphat, and will plead with them there for my people and for my heritage Israel, whom they have scattered among the nations, and parted my land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's promise to judge the nations for their mistreatment of Israel, affirming His protection of His chosen people.

keyVerses.text: Multitudes, multitudes in the valley of decision: for the day of the LORD is near in the valley of decision.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the imminence and seriousness of God's judgment, calling all to recognize the Day of the LORD.

keyVerses.text: The LORD also shall roar out of Zion, and utter his voice from Jerusalem; and the heavens and the earth shall shake: but the LORD will be the hope of his people, and the strength of the children of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's power in judgment and His role as the protector and strength of His people.

keyVerses.text: But Judah shall dwell for ever, and Jerusalem from generation to generation.
keyVerses.significance: It assures the eternal security and blessing of God's covenant people despite trials and judgment.
